trans-unit.source: Upload a custom Java web app to Azure
trans-unit.target: Upload a custom Java web app to Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to upload a custom Java web app to Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to upload a custom Java web app to Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Upload a custom Java web app to Azure
trans-unit.target: Upload a custom Java web app to Azure

trans-unit.source: This topic explains how to upload a custom Java web app to [Azure App Service] Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains how to upload a custom Java web app to [Azure App Service] Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Included is information that applies to any Java website or web app, and also some examples for specific applications.
trans-unit.target: Included is information that applies to any Java website or web app, and also some examples for specific applications.

trans-unit.source: Note that Azure provides a means for creating Java web apps using the Azure preview portal's configuration UI, and the Azure Marketplace, as documented at [Create a Java web app in Azure App Service](web-sites-java-get-started.md).
trans-unit.target: Note that Azure provides a means for creating Java web apps using the Azure preview portal's configuration UI, and the Azure Marketplace, as documented at [Create a Java web app in Azure App Service](web-sites-java-get-started.md).

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is for scenarios in which you do not want to use the portal configuration UI or the Azure Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is for scenarios in which you do not want to use the portal configuration UI or the Azure Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: Configuration guidelines
trans-unit.target: Configuration guidelines

trans-unit.source: The following describes the settings expected for custom Java web apps on Azure.
trans-unit.target: The following describes the settings expected for custom Java web apps on Azure.

trans-unit.source: The HTTP port used by the Java process is dynamically assigned.
trans-unit.target: The HTTP port used by the Java process is dynamically assigned.

trans-unit.source: The process must use the port from the environment variable `HTTP_PLATFORM_PORT`.
trans-unit.target: The process must use the port from the environment variable `HTTP_PLATFORM_PORT`.

trans-unit.source: All listen ports other than the single HTTP listener should be disabled.
trans-unit.target: All listen ports other than the single HTTP listener should be disabled.

trans-unit.source: In Tomcat, that includes the shutdown, HTTPS, and AJP ports.
trans-unit.target: In Tomcat, that includes the shutdown, HTTPS, and AJP ports.

trans-unit.source: The container needs to be configured for IPv4 traffic only.
trans-unit.target: The container needs to be configured for IPv4 traffic only.

trans-unit.source: The **startup** command for the application needs to be set in the configuration.
trans-unit.target: The **startup** command for the application needs to be set in the configuration.

trans-unit.source: Applications that require directories with write permission need to be located in the Azure web app's content directory, which is **D:\home**.
trans-unit.target: Applications that require directories with write permission need to be located in the Azure web app's content directory, which is **D:\home**.

trans-unit.source: The environmental variable `HOME` refers to D:\home.
trans-unit.target: The environmental variable `HOME` refers to D:\home.

trans-unit.source: You can set environment variables as required in the web.config file.
trans-unit.target: You can set environment variables as required in the web.config file.

trans-unit.source: web.config httpPlatform configuration
trans-unit.target: web.config httpPlatform configuration

trans-unit.source: The following information describes the **httpPlatform** format within web.config.
trans-unit.target: The following information describes the **httpPlatform** format within web.config.

trans-unit.source: **arguments** (Default="").
trans-unit.target: **arguments** (Default="").

trans-unit.source: Arguments to the executable or script specified in the **processPath** setting.
trans-unit.target: Arguments to the executable or script specified in the **processPath** setting.

trans-unit.source: Examples (shown with **processPath** included):
trans-unit.target: Examples (shown with **processPath** included):

trans-unit.source: **processPath** - Path to the executable or script that will launch a process listening for HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: **processPath** - Path to the executable or script that will launch a process listening for HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: Examples:
trans-unit.target: Examples:

trans-unit.source: **rapidFailsPerMinute** (Default=10.) Number of times the process specified in **processPath** is allowed to crash per minute.
trans-unit.target: **rapidFailsPerMinute** (Default=10.) Number of times the process specified in **processPath** is allowed to crash per minute.

trans-unit.source: If this limit is exceeded, **HttpPlatformHandler** will stop launching the process for the remainder of the minute.
trans-unit.target: If this limit is exceeded, **HttpPlatformHandler** will stop launching the process for the remainder of the minute.

trans-unit.source: **requestTimeout** (Default="00:02:00".) Duration for which **HttpPlatformHandler** will wait for a response from the process listening on `%HTTP_PLATFORM_PORT%`.
trans-unit.target: **requestTimeout** (Default="00:02:00".) Duration for which **HttpPlatformHandler** will wait for a response from the process listening on `%HTTP_PLATFORM_PORT%`.

trans-unit.source: **startupRetryCount** (Default=10.) Number of times **HttpPlatformHandler** will try to launch the process specified in **processPath**.
trans-unit.target: **startupRetryCount** (Default=10.) Number of times **HttpPlatformHandler** will try to launch the process specified in **processPath**.

trans-unit.source: See **startupTimeLimit** for more details.
trans-unit.target: See **startupTimeLimit** for more details.

trans-unit.source: **startupTimeLimit** (Default=10 seconds.) Duration for which **HttpPlatformHandler** will wait for the executable/script to start a process listening on the port.
trans-unit.target: **startupTimeLimit** (Default=10 seconds.) Duration for which **HttpPlatformHandler** will wait for the executable/script to start a process listening on the port.

trans-unit.source: If this time limit is exceeded, **HttpPlatformHandler** will kill the process and try to launch it again **startupRetryCount** times.
trans-unit.target: If this time limit is exceeded, **HttpPlatformHandler** will kill the process and try to launch it again **startupRetryCount** times.

trans-unit.source: **stdoutLogEnabled** (Default="true".) If true, **stdout** and **stderr** for the process specified in the **processPath** setting will be redirected to the file specified in **stdoutLogFile** (see **stdoutLogFile** section).
trans-unit.target: **stdoutLogEnabled** (Default="true".) If true, **stdout** and **stderr** for the process specified in the **processPath** setting will be redirected to the file specified in **stdoutLogFile** (see **stdoutLogFile** section).

trans-unit.source: **stdoutLogFile** (Default="d:\home\LogFiles\httpPlatformStdout.log".) Absolute file path for which **stdout** and **stderr** from the process specified in **processPath** will be logged.
trans-unit.target: **stdoutLogFile** (Default="d:\home\LogFiles\httpPlatformStdout.log".) Absolute file path for which **stdout** and **stderr** from the process specified in **processPath** will be logged.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] `%HTTP_PLATFORM_PORT%` is a special placeholder which needs to specified either as part of **arguments** or as part of the **httpPlatform** **environmentVariables** list.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] `%HTTP_PLATFORM_PORT%` is a special placeholder which needs to specified either as part of **arguments** or as part of the **httpPlatform** **environmentVariables** list.

trans-unit.source: This will be replaced by an internally generated port by **HttpPlatformHandler** so that the process specified by **processPath** can listen on this port.
trans-unit.target: This will be replaced by an internally generated port by **HttpPlatformHandler** so that the process specified by **processPath** can listen on this port.

trans-unit.source: Deployment
trans-unit.target: Deployment

trans-unit.source: Java based web apps can be deployed easily through most of the same means that are used with the Internet Information Services (IIS) based web applications.
trans-unit.target: Java based web apps can be deployed easily through most of the same means that are used with the Internet Information Services (IIS) based web applications.

trans-unit.source: FTP, Git and Kudu are all supported as deployment mechanisms, as is the integrated SCM capability for web apps.
trans-unit.target: FTP, Git and Kudu are all supported as deployment mechanisms, as is the integrated SCM capability for web apps.

trans-unit.source: WebDeploy works as a protocol, however, as Java is not developed in Visual Studio, WebDeploy does not fit with Java web app deployment use cases.
trans-unit.target: WebDeploy works as a protocol, however, as Java is not developed in Visual Studio, WebDeploy does not fit with Java web app deployment use cases.

trans-unit.source: Application configuration Examples
trans-unit.target: Application configuration Examples

trans-unit.source: For the following applications, a web.config file and the application configuration is provided as examples to show how to enable your Java application on App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: For the following applications, a web.config file and the application configuration is provided as examples to show how to enable your Java application on App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Tomcat
trans-unit.target: Tomcat

trans-unit.source: While there are two variations on Tomcat that are supplied with App Service Web Apps, it is still quite possible to upload customer specific instances.
trans-unit.target: While there are two variations on Tomcat that are supplied with App Service Web Apps, it is still quite possible to upload customer specific instances.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example of an install of Tomcat with a different Java Virtual Machine (JVM).
trans-unit.target: Below is an example of an install of Tomcat with a different Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

trans-unit.source: On the Tomcat side, there are a few configuration changes that need to be made.
trans-unit.target: On the Tomcat side, there are a few configuration changes that need to be made.

trans-unit.source: The server.xml needs to be edited to set:
trans-unit.target: The server.xml needs to be edited to set:

trans-unit.source: Shutdown port = -1
trans-unit.target: Shutdown port = -1

trans-unit.source: HTTP connector port = {port.http}
trans-unit.target: HTTP connector port = {port.http}

trans-unit.source: HTTP connector address = "127.0.0.1"
trans-unit.target: HTTP connector address = "127.0.0.1"

trans-unit.source: Comment out HTTPS and AJP connectors
trans-unit.target: Comment out HTTPS and AJP connectors

trans-unit.source: The IPv4 setting can also be set in the catalina.properties file where you can add `java.net.preferIPv4Stack=true`
trans-unit.target: The IPv4 setting can also be set in the catalina.properties file where you can add `java.net.preferIPv4Stack=true`

trans-unit.source: Direct3d calls are not supported on App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Direct3d calls are not supported on App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: To disable those, add the following Java option should your application make such calls: `-Dsun.java2d.d3d=false`
trans-unit.target: To disable those, add the following Java option should your application make such calls: `-Dsun.java2d.d3d=false`

trans-unit.source: Jetty
trans-unit.target: Jetty

trans-unit.source: As is the case for Tomcat, customers can upload their own instances for Jetty.
trans-unit.target: As is the case for Tomcat, customers can upload their own instances for Jetty.

trans-unit.source: In the case of running the full install of Jetty, the configuration would look like this:
trans-unit.target: In the case of running the full install of Jetty, the configuration would look like this:

trans-unit.source: The Jetty configuration needs to be changed in the start.ini to set `java.net.preferIPv4Stack=true`.
trans-unit.target: The Jetty configuration needs to be changed in the start.ini to set `java.net.preferIPv4Stack=true`.

trans-unit.source: Hudson
trans-unit.target: Hudson

trans-unit.source: Our test used the Hudson 3.1.2 war and the default Tomcat 7.0.50 instance but without using the UI to set things up.
trans-unit.target: Our test used the Hudson 3.1.2 war and the default Tomcat 7.0.50 instance but without using the UI to set things up.

trans-unit.source: Because Hudson is a software build tool, it is advised to install it on dedicated instances where the **AlwaysOn** flag can be set on the web app.
trans-unit.target: Because Hudson is a software build tool, it is advised to install it on dedicated instances where the **AlwaysOn** flag can be set on the web app.

trans-unit.source: In your web app’s root directory, i.e., **d:\home\site\wwwroot**, create a **webapps** directory (if not already present), and place Hudson.war in **d:\home\site\wwwroot\webapps**.
trans-unit.target: In your web app’s root directory, i.e., **d:\home\site\wwwroot**, create a **webapps** directory (if not already present), and place Hudson.war in **d:\home\site\wwwroot\webapps**.

trans-unit.source: Download apache maven 3.0.5 (compatible with Hudson) and place it in **d:\home\site\wwwroot**.
trans-unit.target: Download apache maven 3.0.5 (compatible with Hudson) and place it in **d:\home\site\wwwroot**.

trans-unit.source: Create web.config in **d:\home\site\wwwroot** and paste the following contents in it:
trans-unit.target: Create web.config in **d:\home\site\wwwroot** and paste the following contents in it:

trans-unit.source: At this point the web app can be restarted to take the changes.
trans-unit.target: At this point the web app can be restarted to take the changes.

trans-unit.source: Connect to http://yourwebapp/hudson to start Hudson.
trans-unit.target: Connect to http://yourwebapp/hudson to start Hudson.

trans-unit.source: After Hudson configures itself, you should see the following screen:
trans-unit.target: After Hudson configures itself, you should see the following screen:

trans-unit.source: Hudson
trans-unit.target: Hudson

trans-unit.source: Access the Hudson configuration page: Click **Manage Hudson**, and then click **Configure System**.
trans-unit.target: Access the Hudson configuration page: Click **Manage Hudson**, and then click **Configure System**.

trans-unit.source: Configure the JDK as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Configure the JDK as shown below:

trans-unit.source: Hudson configuration
trans-unit.target: Hudson configuration

trans-unit.source: Configure Maven as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Configure Maven as shown below:

trans-unit.source: Maven configuration
trans-unit.target: Maven configuration

trans-unit.source: Save the settings.
trans-unit.target: Save the settings.

trans-unit.source: Hudson should now be configured and ready for use.
trans-unit.target: Hudson should now be configured and ready for use.

trans-unit.source: For additional information on Hudson, see [http://hudson-ci.org](http://hudson-ci.org).
trans-unit.target: For additional information on Hudson, see [http://hudson-ci.org](http://hudson-ci.org).

trans-unit.source: Liferay
trans-unit.target: Liferay

trans-unit.source: Liferay is supported on App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Liferay is supported on App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Since Liferay can require significant memory, the web app needs to run on a medium or large dedicated worker, which can provide enough memory.
trans-unit.target: Since Liferay can require significant memory, the web app needs to run on a medium or large dedicated worker, which can provide enough memory.

trans-unit.source: Liferay also takes several minutes to start up.
trans-unit.target: Liferay also takes several minutes to start up.

trans-unit.source: For that reason, it is recommended that you set the web app to **Always On**.
trans-unit.target: For that reason, it is recommended that you set the web app to **Always On**.

trans-unit.source: Using Liferay 6.1.2 Community Edition GA3 bundled with Tomcat, the following files were edited after downloading Liferay:
trans-unit.target: Using Liferay 6.1.2 Community Edition GA3 bundled with Tomcat, the following files were edited after downloading Liferay:

trans-unit.source: Server.xml
trans-unit.target: Server.xml

trans-unit.source: Change Shutdown port to -1.
trans-unit.target: Change Shutdown port to -1.

trans-unit.source: Change HTTP connector to
trans-unit.target: Change HTTP connector to

trans-unit.source: Comment out the AJP connector.
trans-unit.target: Comment out the AJP connector.

trans-unit.source: In the **liferay\tomcat-7.0.40\webapps\ROOT\WEB-INF\classes** folder, create a file named **portal-ext.properties**.
trans-unit.target: In the **liferay\tomcat-7.0.40\webapps\ROOT\WEB-INF\classes** folder, create a file named **portal-ext.properties**.

trans-unit.source: This file needs to contain one line, as shown here:
trans-unit.target: This file needs to contain one line, as shown here:

trans-unit.source: At the same directory level as the tomcat-7.0.40 folder, create a file named **web.config** with the following content:
trans-unit.target: At the same directory level as the tomcat-7.0.40 folder, create a file named **web.config** with the following content:

trans-unit.source: Under the **httpPlatform** block, the **requestTimeout** is set to “00:10:00”.
trans-unit.target: Under the **httpPlatform** block, the **requestTimeout** is set to “00:10:00”.

trans-unit.source: It can be reduced but then you are likely to see some timeout errors while Liferay is bootstrapping.
trans-unit.target: It can be reduced but then you are likely to see some timeout errors while Liferay is bootstrapping.

trans-unit.source: If this value is changed, then the **connectionTimeout** in the tomcat server.xml should also be modified.
trans-unit.target: If this value is changed, then the **connectionTimeout** in the tomcat server.xml should also be modified.

trans-unit.source: It is worth noting that the JRE_HOME environnment varariable is specified in the above web.config to point to the 64-bit JDK.
trans-unit.target: It is worth noting that the JRE_HOME environnment varariable is specified in the above web.config to point to the 64-bit JDK.

trans-unit.source: The default is 32-bit, but since Liferay may require high levels of memory, it is recommended to use the 64-bit JDK.
trans-unit.target: The default is 32-bit, but since Liferay may require high levels of memory, it is recommended to use the 64-bit JDK.

trans-unit.source: Once you make these changes, restart your web app running Liferay, Then, open http://yourwebapp.
trans-unit.target: Once you make these changes, restart your web app running Liferay, Then, open http://yourwebapp.

trans-unit.source: The Liferay portal is available from the web app root.
trans-unit.target: The Liferay portal is available from the web app root.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Liferay, see [http://www.liferay.com](http://www.liferay.com).
trans-unit.target: For more information on Liferay, see [http://www.liferay.com](http://www.liferay.com).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
